label: real
article:
The biggest difference between November 3rd, 2016 and November 3rd, 2020? Fear. The historian Timothy Snyder on the US election and what happens in the country.
Timothy David
Snyder is is the Richard C. Levin Professor of History at Yale University and a
permanent fellow at the Institute for Human Sciences in Vienna. In his 2017 book
"On Tyranny," he provided a guide for resisting authoritarian regime change
that is used the world over. His most recent book, "Our
Malady: Lessons in Liberty from a Hospital Diary," will be published in
September.
Lesen Sie das Interview auf Deutsch.
ZEIT ONLINE: Professor Snyder, in your forthcoming book,
you describe your experience with the American health-care system. What was it
like?
Timothy Snyder: I was very ill and I was in the emergency room
for a very long time before anything happened. The doctors made a series of
mistakes which almost killed me. I was in several different hospitals, but by
the end I was in one close to home. I thought I would be well taken care of, or
that at least I would understand the flaws of the system. I didn't, though. Afterwards
some colleagues berated me because I did not call on powerful patrons to help
me when I was in the emergency room. I was shocked by this open admission by
American elites that our hospitals don't really function unless you have
protection. Medicine should not be a matter of patronage or oligarchy. It
should simply work.
ZEIT ONLINE: That sounds dramatic. 
Snyder: It takes some work to explain this to
Europeans or Germans. It's a little like speaking a different language. When
you inside an American hospital, you have to think differently and constantly be asking yourself: Are
the doctors and the nurses doing this for a reason that has to do with health,
or are they doing it for a reason that has to do with money? When I am in a
hospital in Germany or in Austria, I might be dissatisfied with something, and
indeed sometimes I am. But honestly, in Europe I am never worried that money is
guiding the process. And so the whole mood is different, and in a way that has
to be beneficial for health.
ZEIT ONLINE: How do you explain the difference?
Snyder: The fundamental problem with the American
health-care system is that it is commercial, it is based on profit. This means
that everyone is affected by this, not just bodily but also morally. We are all
demoralized, because even those of us who have some access to health care know
that we have it at the expense of others. Especially during this pandemic, we
are seeing how this affects American life. Roughly half of Americans feel they
can't go to the hospital because they cannot afford it. Without sick leave or
decent unemployment compensation, we cannot keep the ill out of the workplace
during an epidemic. Since we lack the basic idea of public health, a crisis
like the coronavirus is all the more deadly. There is no national mechanism to
create an emergency response, whether it is about testing or anything else.
What my own time in the hospital revealed to me, and what the coronavirus has
revealed on a national level, is that a purely commercial medical system is
always going to fail in times of crisis.
ZEIT ONLINE: What does the broken health-care system tell
us about the state of democracy in the U.S.?
Snyder: It tells us many things. Our flawed health care
makes democracy harder, and our flawed democracy makes health care harder. American
democracy is compromised by racism in the very basic sense that it is harder
for people who are not white to vote. This makes building a welfare state more
difficult. Republican politicians tell white Americans that we can't have a
public health system because only black people and immigrants would profit from
it. And the lack of a functioning welfare state creates a great deal of fear
and anxiety. This in turn pushes us towards authoritarianism and away from
democracy. You can watch on the news right now as the president seeks to
transform all of this entirely unnecessary fear and death into the emotional foundation
for the shift toward authoritarianism. 
ZEIT ONLINE: These are all problems that the United States
has been facing for several decades. Now, on top of all that, Donald Trump is
sitting in the White House. In you book "On Tyranny," which was published 2017, you warned that
democratic institutions may not be able to defend themselves. Three years
later, everything you predicted seems to have come true.
Snyder: Sadly, things have unfolded in the United States essentially as I expected they would. The consensus in the United States
in late 2016 was that the institutions would defend themselves. I didn't
believe that, which is why I wrote "On
Tyranny." I wanted Americans to take individual responsibility for
civic affairs and to try to rebuild the institutions while there was time.
Obviously, things are much worse today than they were in 2017. Inequality of
wealth is worse. Access to local news is worse. Racism is clearly worse, both
against African Americans and against immigrants. 
ZEIT ONLINE:Donald Trump is openly hinting that he might
not accept the result of the election in November. What would happen if he was
to refuse to leave the White House despite losing?
Snyder: I guess he would have to sleep in the guest
room.
ZEIT ONLINE: That sounds rather optimistic.
Snyder: I was just trying to make you laugh.
Seriously, Donald Trump is not a democrat. He does not actually like
democracies. And he has said dozens of times that he does not accept the
outcomes of elections. He has made it abundantly clear that he should be allowed
to decide who wins and who loses. So when Donald Trump talks about possible
electoral fraud, he wants to create an atmosphere of chaos surrounding the November
election. Basically, everything he has said and done since summer is about
chaos: the idea that we are experiencing riots in our cities; the idea that you
can't trust mail-in voting, even though that's the most reliable way to do it.
He is hoping that he can somehow emerge from that chaos as president. 
ZEIT ONLINE: The Black Lives Matter protests have been
accompanied by looting and violence …
Snyder: It would be such a good thing if we could
start a sentence with the word "Black" and finish it without using
the words "looting" and "violence." I took part in those
protests, as I have taken part in protests since the beginning. The protests, which
I think have been inadequately covered in Europe, are  the largest expression of American civic
resistance since the 1960s and have been largely, indeed overwhelmingly,
peaceful. The hundreds of small protests all throughout the country do not get
noticed. Only when something burns do we take photos and pay attention. These
protests are actually showing that a population can be mobilized for a moral
cause even during a pandemic. 
ZEIT ONLINE: Do you think the institutions in America are
prepared for a president refusing to leave office?


Snyder: They're not prepared, but they are preparing
and they're preparing on both sides. There are lawyers who are preparing the
lawsuits. And there are politicians who are trying to make sure that the right
kind of majorities can be assembled in the House of Representatives. Ahead of
November and in November, there will be a clash, there will be disorder for a
certain period of time. But I think in the end, it will be clear that Joe Biden
has won. Unlike in 2016, when I was one of the very few people warning that we
were facing a crisis of institutions in 2020, that the next election could be
the last more or less normal one, everyone on the democratic side is now aware
that this election is about regime change and not just about one candidate
versus another.
ZEIT ONLINE: How long will it take to get Donald Trump out
of office?
Snyder: In many countries, you have a new president or
a new prime minister just a few days after an election. But that is not the way
our system works. We have an election in the first week of November and then a
transfer of power in the third week of January. It is important that American
and also foreign journalists cover this the right way. Trump will claim, and is
already claiming, that if we do not know the outcome on election day, then we
have a crisis. This is self-serving and wrong. It is not true that we have to
know the projected outcome of the election on the day people have voted. It is
just a luxury which we are used to having. The truth is: The formal outcome of
the election is decided in December, so we have five weeks to count all of the
votes. (Editor's note: December is when
the Electoral College votes for the new president and vice president.)
ZEIT ONLINE: The potential
legal and political battles after the elections are one thing. Another thing is
what is happening on the streets of the U.S.. Donald Trump managed to get armed
supporters inside the Michigan State Capitol with just a few tweets. How severe is the
risk that violence will break out?
Snyder: Unfortunately, Donald Trump is begging for
violence. And unfortunately, there will be violence. In Kenosha a young man has already killed protestors. Americans are not better or worse
than anyone else in this respect. If you look at the history of Europe and
contested elections, especially in the first half of the 20th century, violence
was very common. Donald Trump, as you quite correctly suggest, believes that
violence will help him. He knows that he is going to lose the election at the
ballot box. At this point, he is not even trying to win in the conventional
sense.
ZEIT ONLINE: Donald Trump is no longer interested in
winning?
Snyder: He is interested in dying in his own bed,
preferably in the White House and not in prison. I that sense, he is an
utterly typical authoritarian. I mean that he
is not trying to get the most votes, because he knows that he cannot. If he
were trying to win by getting the most votes, the Republican National
Convention would have been much more centrist rather than being so radical. Donald
Trump wouldn't be constantly rallying his base, including its extremist
elements. He would be using conciliatory language, trying to convince people in
the center. But he is not doing that at all. The reason is that he has given
up. He is now trying to gather enough people on the streets and in the
institutions in the hope that somehow things will turn out in his favor after
the election. 
ZEIT ONLINE: Some have discussed the possibility of a civil
war. Are such concerns exaggerated?
Snyder: I don't think there will be anything like a
civil war. Donald Trump's supporters, although often angry and often armed, are
not organized in the same way, let us say, that the Heimwehr in Austria was
organized in the 1930s. 
ZEIT ONLINE: So following a few weeks of uncertainty, a
handful of lawsuits and maybe some civil unrest, everything will return to
normal?
Snyder: Look, it is senseless
to try to predict in detail, because what happens depends on how people behave
between now and then. The best we can do is explain the real risks in the hopes
that others take precautions. If we say now that we know what will happen, that
is like saying there is no reason to act. And of course we have to act: We have
to vote, we have to organize, we have to mobilize, and we have to prepare those
lawsuits that you mentioned. I don’t think that we will return to normal as
such. It will hopefully be a time of dramatic change. Because as you said at
the very beginning of the interview, Donald Trump is only part of the problem. He
has only made the existing trends from the last 40 years worse. Which means
that the next administration has to start by addressing the trends of the last
40 years.
ZEIT ONLINE: What should a Biden administration tackle
first?
Snyder: First of all, the Democrats don't just have to
win the White House, but also a majority in the Senate. Assuming they will be
able to achieve that, the most important piece of legislation is one which the
House of Representatives has already tried to pass: cleaning up American
elections. We have huge problems with our elections: The districts are all
wrong, there is too much money in politics, 25 of the 50 states have electoral
repression laws, and Election Day is a Tuesday, when many have to go work
instead of casting their vote.
The second
most important thing is inequality. Massive inequality of wealth between
citizens creates the sense that Americans are not living in the same country.
Inequality of wealth has to be addressed by higher taxation: We are not taxing and
auditing rich people right now, we are only taxing and auditing the middle
class. Not just in the IRS but throughout the government, the people who should
be enforcing the rules are insufficiently funded and are unable to take on the largest
targets. The big internet companies should be broken up and taxed to support
local news: Indeed, one massive inequality we are currently facing is that of
access to relevant information. And racial inequality has to be addressed by
allowing all people to vote and by continuing a national conversation about our
history.
ZEIT ONLINE: Are we making the same mistakes as in 2016,
when many were so sure that Hillary Clinton would win? Is the same thing
happening with Joe Biden's candidacy? 
Snyder: That is a good question to ask, but the
numbers are really very different this time. In 2016, Hillary Clinton's lead
was around two, three or maybe four percentage points. And Clinton was doing
really poorly in the swing states. Biden's lead now is eight or 10 points, and
he is doing well in most of the swing states. It is unusual to have this big of
a gap between the two candidates. 
In 2016,
people were ignoring the data showing that Trump really had a chance. People
just refused to believe it because they were caught in their own bubbles.
Today, everyone is wondering the same thing that you are asking. Democrats are
asking themselves: Are we being too complacent this time? Last time, the
Sanders faction and the Clinton faction felt like they could fight among
themselves because everyone took for granted that Clinton was going to win.
They were not afraid in 2016. They are afraid this time. 
ZEIT ONLINE: You sound very confident.
Snyder: I think Donald Trump is probably more
politically gifted than I am. And he has made clear that thinks that he has
lost the election conventionally. So I'm just going to trust his judgment on
this.
